description: Example of a Global Kafka Dashboard for DC/OS 1.12

panels.description: Average messages per second per Kafka broker
panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (1m) by Topic

panels.description: Average messages per second per Kafka broker
panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (5m) by Topic

panels.description: Average messages per second per Kafka broker
panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (15m) by Topic

panels.description: Number of leaders on this broker. This should be mostly even across all brokers. If not, set auto.leader.rebalance.enable to true on all brokers in the cluster.
panels.title: Number of Leaders per (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Number of partitions on this broker. This should be mostly even across all brokers.
panels.title: Partition Count Across Brokers (Service / Broker)

panels.description: The first node to boot in a Kafka cluster automatically becomes the controller, and there can be only one. The controller in a Kafka cluster is responsible for maintaining the list of partition leaders, and coordinating leadership transitions (in the event a partition leader becomes unavailable). If it becomes necessary to replace the controller, a new controller is randomly chosen by ZooKeeper from the pool of brokers. In general, it is not possible for this value to be greater than one, but you should definitely alert on a value of zero that lasts for more than a short period (< 1s) of time.
panels.title: ActiveControllerCount

panels.description:
In a healthy cluster, the number of in sync replicas (ISRs) should be exactly equal to the total number of replicas. If partition replicas fall too far behind their leaders, the follower partition is removed from the ISR pool, and you should see a corresponding increase in IsrShrinksPerSec. Since Kafka’s high-availability guarantees cannot be met without replication, investigation is certainly warranted should this metric value exceed zero for extended time periods.

If this metric has a value greater than 1 it means that data is not being replicated to enough number of brokers thereby increasing the probability of data loss.
panels.title: Under Replicated Partitions

panels.description: This value should be 0
panels.title: Offline Partitions

panels.description: The first node to boot in a Kafka cluster automatically becomes the controller, and there can be only one. The controller in a Kafka cluster is responsible for maintaining the list of partition leaders, and coordinating leadership transitions (in the event a partition leader becomes unavailable). If it becomes necessary to replace the controller, a new controller is randomly chosen by ZooKeeper from the pool of brokers. In general, it is not possible for this value to be greater than one, but you should definitely alert on a value of zero that lasts for more than a short period (< 1s) of time.
panels.title: Total Partition Count (Service / Broker)

panels.description: The number of in-sync replicas (ISRs) for a particular partition should remain fairly static, the only exceptions are when you are expanding your broker cluster or removing partitions. In order to maintain high availability, a healthy Kafka cluster requires a minimum number of ISRs for failover. A replica could be removed from the ISR pool for a couple of reasons: it is too far behind the leader’s offset (user-configurable by setting the replica.lag.max.messages configuration parameter), or it has not contacted the leader for some time (configurable with the replica.socket.timeout.ms parameter). No matter the reason, an increase in IsrShrinksPerSec without a corresponding increase in IsrExpandsPerSec shortly thereafter is cause for concern and requires user intervention.The Kafka documentation provides a wealth of information on the user-configurable parameters for brokers.
panels.title: ISR Expansion Rate (Service / Broker)

panels.description: The number of in-sync replicas (ISRs) for a particular partition should remain fairly static, the only exceptions are when you are expanding your broker cluster or removing partitions. In order to maintain high availability, a healthy Kafka cluster requires a minimum number of ISRs for failover. A replica could be removed from the ISR pool for a couple of reasons: it is too far behind the leader’s offset (user-configurable by setting the replica.lag.max.messages configuration parameter), or it has not contacted the leader for some time (configurable with the replica.socket.timeout.ms parameter). No matter the reason, an increase in IsrShrinksPerSec without a corresponding increase in IsrExpandsPerSec shortly thereafter is cause for concern and requires user intervention.The Kafka documentation provides a wealth of information on the user-configurable parameters for brokers.
panels.title: ISR Shrink Rate (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Number of requests waiting in the producer purgatory. This should be non-zero when acks=all is used on the producer.
panels.title: Producer Purgatory Requests Waiting

panels.description: Average messages per second per Kafka broker
panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (1m) per (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Average messages per second per Kafka broker
panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (5m) per (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Average messages per second per Kafka broker
panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (15m) per (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Generally, disk throughput tends to be the main bottleneck in Kafka performance. However, that’s not to say that the network is never a bottleneck. Depending on your use case, hardware, and configuration, the network can quickly become the slowest segment of a message’s trip, especially if you are sending messages across data centers. Tracking network throughput on your brokers gives you more information as to where potential bottlenecks may lie, and can inform decisions like whether or not you should enable end-to-end compression of your messages.
panels.title: All Bytes In (1min) per (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Generally, disk throughput tends to be the main bottleneck in Kafka performance. However, that’s not to say that the network is never a bottleneck. Tracking network throughput on your brokers gives you more information as to where potential bottlenecks may lie, and can inform decisions like whether or not you should enable end-to-end compression of your messages.

Depending on your use case, hardware, and configuration, the network can quickly become the slowest segment of a message’s trip, especially if you are sending messages across data centers. Tracking network throughput on your brokers gives you more information as to where potential bottlenecks may lie, and can inform decisions like whether or not you should enable end-to-end compression of your messages.

panels.description: Time the request waits for the follower. This is non-zero for produce requests when acks=all
panels.title: Avg Time Request Waits for Follower (ms)

panels.description: Size of the request queue. A congested request queue will not be able to process incoming or outgoing requests
panels.title: Current Request Queue Size (Service / Broker)

panels.description: Average total time in ms to serve a specified request
panels.title: Avg Total Time Request Serve (ms)

panels.description: Time to send the response
panels.title: Avg Request Response Time (ms)

panels.description: Time the request waits in the request queue
panels.title: Avg Request Waiting Time in Request Queue (ms)
Avg Request Waiting Time in Response Queue (ms)

panels.description: Time the request is processed at the leader
panels.title: Avg Request Processing Time (ms) at Leader
